title: Is My Windshield Safe?
description: Get instant assessment of existing damage and safety risks

questions.text: What best describes the damage to your windshield?

options.text: A small chip or "bullseye" (smaller than a quarter)
A crack longer than 6 inches or multiple cracks
On the passenger side, away from the edges
Directly in the driver's line of sight
Near the edge of the windshield or in front of a camera sensor

questions.text: Since your last windshield replacement (if any), have you noticed...

options.text: A "whooshing" or wind noise at high speeds
Any signs of water leaks during rain or a car wash

safe.title: Your Windshield Appears Safe
safe.summary: Based on your answers, your windshield seems to be in good condition.
safe.explanation: The modern windshield is a critical safety component, contributing up to 60% of your vehicle's roof strength in a rollover and ensuring proper airbag deployment. Continue with regular care, such as cleaning with ammonia-free products and replacing worn wiper blades, to maintain its integrity.

caution.title: Caution: Repair Recommended
caution.summary: Your windshield has minor damage that should be addressed.
caution.explanation: Small chips and cracks can compromise the structural integrity and are likely to spread due to road vibrations and temperature changes. According to the Repair of Laminated Auto Glass Standard (ROLAGS™), many smaller issues can be professionally repaired, which is cheaper than a replacement and preserves your vehicle's critical factory seal. Don't delay, as a botched DIY repair can be irreversible.

critical.title: Unsafe: Immediate Professional Inspection Required
critical.summary: The damage or issues you've described indicate a significant safety risk.
critical.explanation: Damage in the driver's line of sight, near the edge, or in front of ADAS cameras requires immediate attention. A compromised windshield fails to provide necessary support for the roof and airbags in an accident. Furthermore, any wind noise or water leaks suggest a failed adhesive seal from a previous replacement, which is extremely dangerous. Your vehicle should be inspected by a certified technician immediately. Replacement is required.
